Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: It's curious that you think Project Denver processors are only for the server market. 64 bit ARM is needed in the very next generation of premium mobile products, and in the bulk of the market a generation later. If you look at the configuration of tablets and smartphones, they are currently being shipped with 1GB or 2GB of DRAM. That#$%$ the architectural limit. A 2GB DRAM configuration is the maximum addressable with 32 bit ARM, since the other 2GB of address space is assigned to non-DRAM devices. The obvious PAE-like extension to expand the addressable memory has been introduced, but it's not yet in use. The other obvious market evolution is the leap in display resolution, after being stalled for years. This is adding to the demand for larger directly addressable main memory (PAE doesn't help here) and powerful GPUs. Of course GPUs are second nature to nvidia, since they and ATI have split 90% of the market for the past decade. I don't think nvidia can be a profit-making leader without a 64 bit product. The follow-on question is "did they need to build their own". Like Apple' with A5X and Qualcomm with Krait, nvidia must have decided that they did. Up to a year ago I considered Krait a losing bet by Qualcomm. They invested tens of millions, and ended up with a product that wasn't quite as fast as a drop-in ARM designed core that could be licensed by anyone for under a buck. But it has become clear what it gave them, and now Apple: control. They can introduce products on their own schedule, switch fab lines as needed, and customize bus bandwidth to the product. That's such a huge product integration advantage that no one questioned Apple's recent decision to switch to their own processor core design.

Topic.Title: "Project Denver going great!" says Jen Hsun Huang

Message.Msg: Am I really out of touch? Let’s examine the market dynamics. There are only two markets out there, desktop and server. The demise of PC industry due to consumer preference of tablets over laptop/desktop will put additional pressure on Nvidia to become profitable in a shrinking consumer PC market. Further, according to IDC: “Worldwide server market revenues decline 4.8% in second quarter as market demand softens. On a year-over-year basis, volume systems experienced a 2.5% revenue decline. At the same time, demand for midrange and high-end systems experienced year-over-year revenue declines of 11.2% and 7.6% respectively in 2Q12. All three segments were impacted by difficult year-over-year compares combined with transitions in the technology refresh cycles.” The worldwide server market will continue to decline because companies are cutting down their costs by consolidating into the “cloud”. This trend has actually started back in 2000 when large companies started to rationalize their costs of maintaining large pools of in-house servers. During that time, networks have been also converged to provide server centric (flat network storage) environment called “server-farm”. Today, the same server-farm has now graduated into an Internet-WAN based “cloud server architecture” but the concept remains and has now been expanded to every enterprise, not just to large companies. The reason why 64-bit based ARM chip is attractive in the server arena is mainly due to its inherent low power consumption which is most suited for datacenter. But, now Intel has come up with their own version of low power x86 chip called Atom Gemini that’s specifically designed for server architecture. “HP chose to lead with Centerton server cartridges in its initial production server system, codenamed Gemini, due to the processor’s data-center-class features, such as 64-bit support, hardware virtualization (VTx), error correcting code (ECC) memory, lower power requirements, increased performance and broad software ecosystem. These features, coupled with the revolutionary Gemini infrastructure, make the new Centerton-based servers ideal for hyperscale workloads, where using many extreme low-energy servers densely packed into a small footprint can be much more efficient than fewer standalone servers. Traditional servers rely on dedicated components, including management, networking, storage, power cords and cooling fans in a single enclosure. However, Gemini enclosures are capable of supporting thousands of servers per rack that share these components” -hp Doesn’t this remind you of a glorified SoC? My point is, by the time Denver is in production Nvidia will be competing in the shrinking server market due to consolidations while at the same time competing against an established low energy processor like Intel Gemini. In my view, it will be extremely difficult for Nvidia to be profitable in the desktop and server arena given this market dynamics.

Message.Title: UK court says Apple notice was 'false and misleading,' orders full repayment of Samsung's legal costs
Message.Msg: Justice !!!! UK court says Apple notice was 'false and misleading,' orders full repayment of Samsung's legal costs Nothing truly says "I'm sorry" like a large sum of cash, and Apple will have to open up its wallet to Samsung thanks to "false and misleading" information it published in a court-ordered statement. The decision stems from an earlier UK high court ruling ordering Cupertino to post an apology on its British website stating that the Galaxy Tab didn't copy the iPad. However, according to a new judgement by the the Court of Appeal of England and Wales, the apology it issued contained statements "calculated to produce confusion," like references to unrelated, favorable judgements. Though Apple issued a second apology, the court is taking the unusual step of forcing it to pay all of Samsung's legal fees for the entire case on an "indemnity basis" -- in other words, to compensate the Korean maker for losses suffered due to the original statement.

Message.Title: Tim Cook is Tech 'Lightweight', Says Former Apple Exec
Message.Msg: David Sobotta, a former director of Apple's federal sales group, has criticized current CEO Tim Cook's lack of leadership skills, as well as being "lightweight" in terms of understanding technology. Sobotta, who published a Kindle book pertaining to his 20-year experience at Apple called "The Pomme Company" (Pomme being French for apple) spoke about Steve Jobs' successor in an interview. When asked for his thoughts of the recent firing of iOS chief Scott Forstall, which was purportedly due to his lack of apology for Apple's abysmal iOS maps app, and retail chief John Brownell, Sobotta said: "Tim will react to the numbers or his fear of being wrong quickly. Fear of being wrong is a managerial trait that runs strong and deep in Apple because of the way Steve ran the company. Even the appearance of being wrong when in the end you might be right is dreaded at Apple." "Technology-wise, I think Tim Cook is a lightweight," he added. "I never felt passion for technology from Tim like I did from Steve and some of the great engineers." Sobotta has previously been critical of Apple in a number of areas on his blog, Applepeels. The titles to some recent posts are "Do Apple Employees Need A Witness Protection Program?", "Has Apple lost its soul?" and "Will Apple Ever Figure Out the Cloud?"

Message.Msg: 1. Bloomberg: Apple Settles HTC Patent Suits in Shift Away From Jobs’ War Plan Apple’s complaints included claims HTC copied the iPhone maker’s technology for detecting phone numbers in e-mails, allowing users to save the information or make a call without dialing. The dispute, which include a case filed in London, also included Apple accusing its rival of copying other features such as “slide to unlock,” multiple screen touches and using various alphabets when sending messages. HTC’s rebuttal included its $300 million purchase of 3G Graphics Co., a company part-owned by HTC Chairwoman Cher Wang, in a bid to leverage that company’s patent claims against Apple to bolster its own defense. The gambit failed when the ITC ruled in November 2011 that Apple’s Macs didn’t infringe two S3 Graphics patents. A separate case before the ITC may have forced Cook to the negotiating table after a judge said Apple would likely face difficulty getting a series of HTC patents invalidated.
